newsitem.title: SPAIN: SOCCER-ATLETICO AND TOTTENHAM BATTLE FOR JUNINHO.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-ATLETICO AND TOTTENHAM BATTLE FOR JUNINHO.

text.p: Atletico of Spain and and Tottenham of England were locked in a battle on Monday to sign Brazilian midfielder Juninho.
Tottenham had looked the favourites when Middlesbrough said they had agreed to sell the player to the English premier league side for 11 million pounds ($18.3 million).
But later Atletico Madrid director general Miguel Angel Gil said he expected to sign the Brazilian. He gave no price but Spanish media put it at $20 million.

"There is nothing signed," said Gil, son of club owner Jesus Gil. "Just a verbal agreement with the player. This morning I have spoken with his club ... and it is normal that the words should be resepected."

Only hours earlier Dave Allen, public relations officer for English first division Middlesbrough, said: "We have accepted the bid from Tottenham and we have informed Juninho. It is now subject to him agreeing personal terms."
However, the London club would not comment on how far negotiations with the Brazilian had reached.
"All I can say is that the play is in play," said Tottenham's chief executive Claude Littner. "Who he goes to is up to him."

Juninho, who is leaving Middlesbrough after they were relegated from the premier league, is understood to favour a move to Spain where he feels greater exposure on television in Brazil would increase his chances of making the national squad for the 1998 World Cup finals.
But both Allen and Littner dismissed reports in Spanish newspapers on Monday that the Brazilian had signed for Atletico Madrid at the weekend.
"That is not true. At the moment Juninho is still a Middlesbrough player," said Allen. "Atletico made an offer some weeks ago but it was derisory.
"Tottenham are the only club we have accepted an offer from and the way is clear for them to discuss terms with Juninho."
